title: Genesis Chapter 46 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 46 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 46 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 46.

questions.question: Where did Israel offer sacrifices unto the God of his father Isaac?
questions.correctAnswer: Beersheba
questions.explanation: Israel offered sacrifices in Beersheba as stated in Genesis 46:1.

questions.question: Who spoke to Israel in the visions of the night?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: God spoke to Israel in the visions of the night according to Genesis 46:2.

questions.question: What did God promise Jacob concerning Egypt?
options: He would make of him a great nation
He would let him rule Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: He would make of him a great nation
questions.explanation: God promised to make of Jacob a great nation in Egypt as per Genesis 46:3.

questions.question: Who did God say would put his hand upon Jacob's eyes?
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph
questions.explanation: God said Joseph would put his hand upon Jacob's eyes as mentioned in Genesis 46:4.

questions.question: What did Pharaoh send for Jacob and his family?
questions.correctAnswer: Wagons
questions.explanation: Pharaoh sent wagons to carry Jacob, his sons, little ones, and wives as recorded in Genesis 46:5.

questions.question: How many souls of Jacob's sons and daughters were there according to Genesis 46:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty and three
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:15 states there were thirty and three souls of his sons and daughters.

questions.question: Who was Jacob's firstborn son?
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben
questions.explanation: Reuben is named as Jacob's firstborn in Genesis 46:8.

questions.question: Which of these sons died in the land of Canaan?
questions.correctAnswer: Er and Onan
questions.explanation: Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan as noted in Genesis 46:12.

questions.question: How many sons were born to Rachel according to Genesis 46:22?
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteen
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:22 states that the sons of Rachel numbered fourteen souls.

questions.question: Who did Joseph marry in Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Asenath, daughter of Potipherah
questions.explanation: Joseph married Asenath, daughter of Potipherah priest of On as described in Genesis 46:20.

questions.question: Who was sent ahead of Jacob to direct his face unto Goshen?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: Judah was sent before Jacob to direct his face unto Goshen according to Genesis 46:28.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 46:29 states that Joseph wept on his father's neck a good while.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:29 records Joseph falling on Israel's neck and weeping a good while.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 46:26, the total souls that came with Jacob into Egypt were seventy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:26 states threescore and six (66) souls came with Jacob, not seventy.

questions.question: True or False: Every shepherd was considered an abomination unto the Egyptians as per Genesis 46:34.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:34 states that every shepherd was an abomination unto the Egyptians.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Genesis 46:33: 'And it shall come to pass, when Pharaoh shall call you, and shall say, What is your ______?'
questions.correctAnswer: occupation
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:33 records Pharaoh asking the brothers 'What is your occupation?'.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 46 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 46 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is anxious about a major life change and fears the unknown. Based on Genesis 46, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: God reassures us not to fear because He is with us and will fulfill His promises
We should rely solely on our own strength to face challenges
Change is always a sign of God's displeasure
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: God reassures us not to fear because He is with us and will fulfill His promises
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:2-4 shows God speaking to Jacob, telling him not to fear going into Egypt because God will be with him and make a great nation from his descendants. This teaches us to trust God's presence and faithfulness in uncertain times.

questions.question: How does Genesis 46 teach us about the importance of obedience to God’s direction in family life?
options: Jacob obeyed God's instruction by moving his whole family to Egypt
Jacob ignored God's command and stayed where he was
Family decisions should be made without consulting God
Only individual obedience matters, not family obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob obeyed God's instruction by moving his whole family to Egypt
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:5-7 records Jacob rising up and taking his entire family and possessions to Egypt as God instructed, demonstrating obedience and trust that impacted his entire household.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation in their family. What example from Genesis 46 highlights the value of family unity and reconciliation?
options: Joseph embraced his father Jacob with tears, showing deep reconciliation and love
Jacob refused to see Joseph after many years
Family members should keep their distance to avoid conflict
Forgiveness is not necessary for family peace
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph embraced his father Jacob with tears, showing deep reconciliation and love
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:29 describes Joseph meeting Jacob, falling on his neck, and weeping, illustrating the power of forgiveness and restored family fellowship.

questions.question: How does Genesis 46 illustrate the biblical principle of stewardship and generosity in daily life?
options: Jacob and his family brought their cattle and goods with them to Egypt, responsibly managing their possessions
Jacob left everything behind when he moved
Possessions are not important for God’s people
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and his family brought their cattle and goods with them to Egypt, responsibly managing their possessions
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:6 shows that Jacob took his cattle and goods with him, demonstrating wise stewardship and responsibility over God’s provisions.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overwhelmed by family responsibilities. Based on Genesis 46, what biblical truth can encourage perseverance through trials?
options: God supports and leads families through challenges, as He assured Jacob He would go down and bring him up from Egypt
Family burdens are a punishment from God
Only individual success matters, not family welfare
Trials should be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: God supports and leads families through challenges, as He assured Jacob He would go down and bring him up from Egypt
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:3-4 shows God’s promise to accompany Jacob and eventually bring him out of Egypt, encouraging believers to rely on God’s sustaining power.

questions.question: What does Genesis 46 teach about humility and contentment in the context of work and occupation?
options: Jacob’s family humbly identified themselves as shepherds, a profession looked down upon, to live in Goshen
They claimed to be wealthy landowners to impress Pharaoh
They avoided honest work to gain favor
Pride in status is more important than honesty
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob’s family humbly identified themselves as shepherds, a profession looked down upon, to live in Goshen
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:32-34 records Joseph instructing his brothers to say they are shepherds, showing humility and honesty in their livelihood despite cultural disdain.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 46 shows that God’s promises include not only personal blessings but also blessings for one’s descendants and household.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: God promised Jacob in Genesis 46:3 to make of him a great nation, which included his descendants and household, showing blessings extend beyond the individual.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 46, Jacob moved to Egypt alone without any family members or possessions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:5-7 clearly states Jacob moved with all his sons, daughters, grandchildren, wives, cattle, and goods, demonstrating the importance of family and stewardship.

questions.question: How does Genesis 46 demonstrate the value of prayer and personal devotion in facing significant life events?
options: God spoke to Jacob in visions at night, showing the importance of seeking God’s guidance through communion
Jacob ignored God's messages and acted on his own
Personal devotion is unnecessary when making decisions
God only communicates through others, not directly
questions.correctAnswer: God spoke to Jacob in visions at night, showing the importance of seeking God’s guidance through communion
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:2 records God speaking to Jacob in night visions, emphasizing the role of prayer and divine guidance in decision-making.

questions.question: A believer struggles with contentment in their family role. What does Genesis 46 teach about contentment and gratitude in family life?
options: Jacob took joy and gratitude in bringing all his family members with him, recognizing their value
Family roles are unimportant and should be ignored
Gratitude is only for personal achievements
Contentment is found in isolation, not family
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob took joy and gratitude in bringing all his family members with him, recognizing their value
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:7 and 15 show Jacob bringing his sons, daughters, and grandchildren, indicating valuing and appreciating family as a blessing.

questions.question: How does Genesis 46 encourage integrity and honesty in work and testimony?
options: Joseph instructs his brothers to honestly declare their occupation as shepherds to Pharaoh
They were advised to lie about their trade to gain favor
Work is not important in God's plan
Integrity is optional in difficult circumstances
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph instructs his brothers to honestly declare their occupation as shepherds to Pharaoh
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:31-33 shows Joseph telling his family to truthfully say they are shepherds, teaching honesty and integrity in daily life.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Genesis 46 teaches us that God’s presence brings _______ even in unfamiliar and challenging circumstances.
questions.correctAnswer: comfort and assurance
questions.explanation: God assures Jacob not to fear going to Egypt because He will be with him (Genesis 46:3-4), showing that His presence brings comfort and assurance.

questions.question: When a believer is called to lead their family through change, how does Genesis 46 model faithful leadership?
options: Jacob leads his family by following God’s direction and preparing them for the move to Egypt
Jacob ignores God and acts impulsively
Leadership means controlling family without seeking God's will
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob leads his family by following God’s direction and preparing them for the move to Egypt
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:5-7 shows Jacob acting in obedience and carefully bringing all his family and possessions to Egypt as God directed, modeling faithful leadership.

questions.question: According to Genesis 46, what role does God’s promise play in our perseverance through trials?
options: God promises to be with His people and bring them through trials, giving hope and strength
God abandons His people in hardships
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to be with His people and bring them through trials, giving hope and strength
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:3-4 shows God’s promise to Jacob that He will go with him into Egypt and bring him back out, encouraging perseverance through God’s faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Genesis 46 encourage believers to be witnesses in their new environments?
options: Joseph proactively informs Pharaoh about his family’s arrival and occupation, showing transparency and witness
Believers should avoid sharing their background
Witnessing is not important in new places
Believers should hide their identity to fit in
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph proactively informs Pharaoh about his family’s arrival and occupation, showing transparency and witness
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:31-32 records Joseph planning to tell Pharaoh about his family and their occupation, exemplifying openness and witness in a new environment.

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 46 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 46.

questions.question: In Genesis 46, God reassures Jacob by telling him He will make him a great nation in Egypt. How does this promise echo earlier covenantal promises made to the patriarchs?
options: It echoes God's promise to Abraham about his descendants becoming a great nation.
It reflects Moses' promise to lead the Israelites out of Egypt.
It parallels David's covenant about an eternal kingdom.
It corresponds to Solomon's promise of wisdom and prosperity.
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes God's promise to Abraham about his descendants becoming a great nation.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:3 shows God reassuring Jacob with a promise similar to that given to Abraham (Genesis 12:2), emphasizing the continuity of the covenant through generations.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Joseph shall put his hand upon thine eyes' in Genesis 46:4, considering the cultural and literary context?
options: It foreshadows Joseph's role in giving Jacob a proper burial.
It symbolizes Joseph leading Jacob into slavery in Egypt.
It indicates Joseph's betrayal of Jacob.
It represents Jacob losing his sight in Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Joseph's role in giving Jacob a proper burial.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:4 foreshadows the later event where Joseph personally buries Jacob, a significant honor in ancient Near Eastern culture, symbolizing care and respect.

questions.question: How does the mention of Beersheba in Genesis 46:1 connect with the broader narrative of the patriarchs?
options: Beersheba is a key location tied to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob's covenantal experiences.
Beersheba is where Moses received the Ten Commandments.
Beersheba was the capital of Egypt during Joseph’s time.
Beersheba is the city where David was anointed king.
questions.correctAnswer: Beersheba is a key location tied to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob's covenantal experiences.
questions.explanation: In Genesis 46:1, Israel (Jacob) offers sacrifices at Beersheba, a site significant throughout Genesis as a place of covenant and divine encounters for the patriarchs (Genesis 21:33, 26:23-25).

questions.question: Which literary device is primarily used in Genesis 46:2 when God calls 'Jacob, Jacob' and Jacob responds 'Here am I'?
options: Repetition to emphasize divine call and response.
Metaphor comparing Jacob to a shepherd.
questions.correctAnswer: Repetition to emphasize divine call and response.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:2 uses repetition ('Jacob, Jacob') to emphasize the importance of God's call and Jacob's readiness, a common device in Hebrew narrative to highlight divine-human interaction.

questions.question: What is the significance of the detailed genealogies of Jacob’s sons and their descendants in Genesis 46:8-27 in the context of ancient Near Eastern culture?
options: They establish tribal identities and inheritance rights vital for the Israelite nation.
They serve as a census for Egyptian taxation purposes.
They function as a historical record of Egyptian nobility.
They provide a list of priests for the tabernacle service.
questions.correctAnswer: They establish tribal identities and inheritance rights vital for the Israelite nation.
questions.explanation: The genealogies in Genesis 46:8-27 affirm tribal lineage, crucial for land inheritance, social structure, and fulfilling God's promises to Abraham’s descendants.

questions.question: In Genesis 46:10, Shaul is described as 'the son of a Canaanitish woman.' What does this indicate about cultural and familial relationships in Jacob's family?
options: It suggests intermarriage with local Canaanite populations.
It confirms all of Jacob's sons were born to Hebrew women.
It reflects a break in the covenant line due to foreign marriage.
It signifies Shaul was not recognized as Jacob's son.
questions.correctAnswer: It suggests intermarriage with local Canaanite populations.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:10 notes Shaul's maternal Canaanite heritage, indicating some integration or intermarriage with local peoples, reflecting complex family and cultural dynamics.

questions.question: How does the listing of the sons of Leah, Rachel, Bilhah, and Zilpah in Genesis 46 reflect the theme of divine providence?
options: It demonstrates God’s care in preserving the family line through multiple mothers.
It shows favoritism toward Leah's children exclusively.
It indicates a rejection of Bilhah and Zilpah’s offspring.
It foreshadows the division of the kingdom of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God’s care in preserving the family line through multiple mothers.
questions.explanation: The enumeration of all mothers’ children in Genesis 46 highlights how God providentially sustains Jacob’s lineage through diverse family branches.

questions.question: In Genesis 46:28-29, Joseph meets his father Israel in Goshen. What is the significance of Goshen in the cultural and theological context of the narrative?
options: Goshen is a fertile land designated for the Israelites to live separately in Egypt.
Goshen is the capital city of Egypt.
Goshen was a Canaanite religious center.
questions.correctAnswer: Goshen is a fertile land designated for the Israelites to live separately in Egypt.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:28-29 places Jacob in Goshen, highlighting a distinct area prepared for the Israelites, reflecting God's provision and foreshadowing Israel's growth in Egypt.

questions.question: How does Joseph’s instruction to his brothers regarding their occupation in Genesis 46:31-34 reflect ancient Egyptian attitudes toward shepherds?
options: Shepherds were considered abominable, so Israelites needed to separate themselves.
Shepherds were highly respected as priests in Egypt.
Egyptians did not have shepherds and thus sought to learn from Israelites.
Shepherds were the ruling class in Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds were considered abominable, so Israelites needed to separate themselves.
questions.explanation: Joseph instructs his brothers to say they are shepherds (Genesis 46:34) because Egyptians despised shepherds, ensuring Israelites would dwell apart, preserving their identity.

questions.question: The total number of souls that came with Jacob into Egypt is given as seventy in Genesis 46:27. What is the theological importance of this number in relation to the Exodus narrative?
options: It establishes the original Israelite population that leads to the Exodus generation.
It indicates the number of tribes that conquered Canaan.
It matches the number of plagues in Egypt.
It identifies the number of Egyptian gods.
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes the original Israelite population that leads to the Exodus generation.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:27’s mention of seventy souls sets the initial number of Israelites in Egypt, forming the basis for the later Exodus account where their multiplication is a key theme.

questions.question: The sending of Judah ahead to Joseph in Genesis 46:28 serves what narrative and theological function?
options: It highlights Judah’s leadership role among the brothers.
It foreshadows Judah’s betrayal of Joseph.
It shows Pharaoh's distrust of Judah.
It prefigures Judah's kingship established much later.
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights Judah’s leadership role among the brothers.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:28 places Judah in a leadership position, prefiguring his prominence in Israel’s history and the Messianic line.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 46, all of Jacob’s sons survived to enter Egypt with him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:12 notes that Er and Onan, sons of Judah, died in Canaan before entering Egypt with Jacob.

questions.question: What is the significance of the detailed naming of Joseph’s sons Manasseh and Ephraim in Genesis 46:20 within the wider biblical narrative?
options: They become heads of two tribes in Israel, reflecting Joseph's special status.
They were Egyptian priests who adopted Israelite religion.
They were the first kings of Israel.
They represent foreign nations hostile to Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: They become heads of two tribes in Israel, reflecting Joseph's special status.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:20 records Joseph’s sons, who become tribal heads, showing Joseph’s unique role and the expansion of Israel through his lineage.

questions.question: The phrase 'all the souls were threescore and ten' in Genesis 46:27 reflects what literary style common in Hebrew Scripture?
options: Use of rounded symbolic numbers to indicate completeness.
questions.correctAnswer: Use of rounded symbolic numbers to indicate completeness.
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:27 uses 'seventy' as a rounded number symbolizing completeness and divine order in the listing of Israel’s family members entering Egypt.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter Genesis 46 portrays the move to Egypt as a fulfillment of God's promise and includes divine assurances to Jacob.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In Genesis 46:3-4, God speaks to Jacob assuring him about going to Egypt and promises to make him a great nation and to bring him back, indicating divine fulfillment.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 46 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 46 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What divine promise did God give to Israel (Jacob) concerning his journey to Egypt?
options: God would make of him a great nation in Egypt
God would abandon him in Egypt
God would not go with him to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: God would make of him a great nation in Egypt
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:3 clearly records God's promise to Jacob that he would become a great nation in Egypt. This reflects God's covenant faithfulness as seen in Genesis 12:2, Exodus 1:7, Deuteronomy 26:5, and Acts 7:6 where God's promises to Abraham's seed are affirmed.

questions.question: How did God identify Himself to Jacob during the vision at night?
options: I am God, the God of thy father
I am the Lord of hosts
I am the King of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: I am God, the God of thy father
questions.explanation: In Genesis 46:3, God identifies Himself as the God of Jacob's father, emphasizing the continuity of the covenant from Isaac to Jacob. This reveals God's unchanging nature (Malachi 3:6), His covenant faithfulness (Exodus 3:6), and His personal relationship with His people (John 8:58).

questions.question: What assurance did God give regarding Jacob's return from Egypt?
options: God will surely bring him up again
Jacob will stay in Egypt forever
Jacob will be forgotten in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: God will surely bring him up again
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:4 highlights God's promise to bring Jacob back from Egypt, underscoring God's providential care and future redemption, echoing themes in Exodus 3:12, Psalm 105:37, Jeremiah 30:10, and Hebrews 11:22 where God's deliverance and restoration are central.

questions.question: Who was to 'put his hand upon Jacob’s eyes' according to God's promise?
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:4 states that Joseph would 'put his hand upon thy eyes,' indicating Joseph's role in honoring Jacob at his death. This foreshadows Christ's role as the faithful intercessor (Hebrews 7:25), and parallels the honor given to patriarchs in death as in Acts 7:15-16 and John 11:43-44.

questions.question: How many total souls came with Jacob into Egypt, excluding his sons’ wives?
questions.correctAnswer: Sixty-six
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:26 specifies that sixty-six souls came with Jacob into Egypt, showing the fulfillment of God's promise and the preservation of the covenant people. This number is consistent with Exodus 1:5 and Psalm 105:37 highlighting God's providential preservation of Israel.

questions.question: What was the occupation of Jacob’s family, as explained to Pharaoh?
questions.correctAnswer: Shepherds
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:32 reveals that Jacob's family were shepherds, which explains their lifestyle and the later tension with Egyptians who considered shepherds abominable (Genesis 46:34). This occupational identity connects with Abraham (Genesis 13:2), Moses (Exodus 3:1), and David (1 Samuel 17:34-35) illustrating God's use of humble vocations for His purposes.

questions.question: Why were the Israelites to claim shepherding as their occupation before Pharaoh?
options: So they might dwell in the land of Goshen
questions.correctAnswer: So they might dwell in the land of Goshen
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:34 explains that claiming shepherding was strategic so that the Israelites could live in Goshen, a fertile land suitable for their flocks, and separate from Egyptians who abhorred shepherds. This shows God's providential arrangement for Israel's survival, aligning with Exodus 8:22-23 and Leviticus 25:34 concerning God's care for His people.

questions.question: Which of Jacob’s sons died in the land of Canaan before going to Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Er and Onan
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:12 states that Er and Onan, sons of Judah, died in Canaan. Their deaths illustrate the consequences of sin and God's judgment (Genesis 38), reflecting themes of human fallenness and divine holiness found throughout Scripture such as Romans 3:23 and Hebrews 12:29.

questions.question: How many sons did Jacob have by Leah according to the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Six sons and one daughter
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:15 identifies the sons of Leah as six, plus his daughter Dinah. This highlights God's blessing and fulfillment of His promise through Leah’s offspring, which is consistent with later genealogies in Numbers 26:23-26 and the fulfillment of the twelve tribes through Jacob's sons (Deuteronomy 33).

questions.question: Who were the sons of Joseph born to him in Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh and Ephraim
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:20 states that Joseph's sons Manasseh and Ephraim were born in Egypt, pointing to the continuation of God's covenant through Joseph. This is a fulfillment of the promise of fruitfulness (Genesis 28:14) and is significant as these sons become tribes of Israel (Joshua 17:3-6; 1 Chronicles 7:20-29).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Jacob bowing on Joseph’s neck and weeping?
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes reunion and restoration
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:29 depicts Jacob and Joseph's emotional reunion, symbolizing God’s restoration of broken relationships and fulfillment of promises. This echoes themes of reconciliation in 2 Corinthians 5:18, Luke 15:20, and Ephesians 2:14, illustrating God's redemptive plan through Christ.

questions.question: What did Jacob say upon seeing Joseph alive after believing him dead?
options: Now let me die, since I have seen thy face
I am the least of all my father's children
questions.correctAnswer: Now let me die, since I have seen thy face
questions.explanation: In Genesis 46:30, Jacob expresses that seeing Joseph alive fulfilled a deep hope, echoing the fulfillment of God’s promises. This reflects the hope in resurrection and life found in John 11:25-26, 1 Corinthians 15:20, and Revelation 21:4.

questions.question: Who did Jacob send ahead to Joseph to direct his face toward Goshen?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:28 states Judah was sent ahead, indicating his leadership role and foreshadowing the Messianic tribe (Genesis 49:10), which aligns with Jesus' lineage (Matthew 1:3-6) and highlights God's sovereign orchestration of history.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a son of Levi listed in Genesis 46?
questions.correctAnswer: Naphtali
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:11 lists Levi's sons as Gershon, Kohath, and Merari, while Naphtali is a separate son of Jacob (Genesis 46:24). This distinction is important for understanding the priestly tribe of Levi and the tribal divisions, as confirmed in Numbers 1 and 3.

questions.question: What was the nationality of Shaul, son of Simeon, as described in the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Canaanitish
questions.explanation: Genesis 46:10 notes Shaul was 'the son of a Canaanitish woman,' highlighting the presence of foreign influence and intermarriage in Israel’s history, a motif discussed in Ezra 9:1-2 and Nehemiah 13:23-27, illustrating God's dealings with holiness and covenant purity.
